channel.title: We been DDOS 8 times in a row today
channel.description:
Amazing how RaW won't give up. Im just amazed that only Sythe out of all the RS2 Cheating Communities has reported it to the police. I mean comon people if you don't want RaW to DDOS cheating sites anymore, we have to report it to the proper authorities.
Post your oppinions here.

item.description:

For you guys who don’t know the acronym DDos or Dos It means “Denial of service”
Basically pinging a website until it’s down and out…
And this is old. Goatee you grave digger -.-

Now everyone knows about it.[/quote]

We don’t know about it… we only know the word and a summary of what it does.

What we want to know is how it does it.

And no, nothing illegal is on this website.[/quote]

I fucking hate myself… back when he was giving out that scam called autorune 2… I wanted to help the people who were getting scammed… so i whoised his site and the asshole actually kept his real stuff… i copy and pasted his info on his site… and then he deleted it… his site (autoruneltd.co.uk) is down now so we cant get back the info… but I think we should

item.title: We been DDOS 8 times in a row today
item.dc:creator: @Taylor Taylor
item.description:
@Taylor wrote:

[quote=“The Hateful Noob, post:73, topic:17574”]what does DDOS stand for?[/quote]Distributed attack

A distributed denial of service attack (DDoS) occurs when multiple compromised systems flood the bandwidth or resources of a targeted system, usually a web server(s). These systems are compromised by attackers using a variety of methods.

Malware can carry DDoS attack mechanisms; one of the more well known examples of this was MyDoom. Its DoS mechanism was triggered on a specific date and time. This type of DDoS involved hardcoding the target IP address prior to release of the malware and no further interaction was necessary to launch the attack.

A system may also be compromised with a trojan, allowing the attacker to download a zombie agent (or the trojan may contain one). Attackers can also break into systems using automated tools that exploit flaws in programs that listen for connections from remote hosts. This scenario primarily concerns systems acting as servers on the web.

Stacheldraht is a classic example of a DDoS tool. It utilizes a layered structure where the attacker uses a client program to connect to handlers which are compromised systems that issue commands to the zombie agents which in turn facilitate the DDoS attack. Agents are compromised via the handlers by the attacker using automated routines to exploit vulnerabilities in programs that accept remote connections running on the targeted remote hosts. Each handler can control up to a thousand agents.[1]

These collections of compromised systems are known as botnets, DDoS tools like stacheldraht still use classic DoS attack methods centered around ip spoofing and amplification like smurf and fraggle attacks (these are also known as bandwidth consumption attacks), SYN floods (also known as resource starvation attacks) may also be used. Newer tools can use DNS servers for DoS purposes. (see next section)

Unlike MyDooms DDoS mechanism botnets can be turned against any ip address. Script kiddies use them to deny the availability of well known websites to legitimate users.[2] More sophisticated attackers will use DDoS tools for the purposes of extortion and even against their business rivals.[3]

It is important to note the difference between a DDoS and DoS attack. If an attacker mounts a smurf attack from a single host it would be classed as a DoS attack. In fact any attack against availability e.g. using High-energy radio-frequency weapons to render computer equipment inoperable would be classed as a Denial of Service attack albeit an exotic one.[4] On the other hand if an attacker uses a thousand zombie systems to simultaneously launch smurf attacks against a remote host this would be classed as a DDoS attack.

Read full topic

item.title: We been DDOS 8 times in a row today
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:4, topic:17574”]About reporting him to the authorities, what authorities? what is his name? where does he live? We don’t really have solid evidence of any of those things.

And no, nothing illegal is on this website.[/quote]

Josh Watkins. That hosting info that people keep posting has gone through Michael Watkins, Josh Watkins, and Michael Kane. He lives somewhere in Devon (at least, AutoRune Ltd. is out of Plymouth).

There’s an M Watkins:

M WATKINS

33 CEDAR CLOSE
CALLINGTON
CORNWALL
PL177HG

01579 382 520

On several occasions the professed owner of a registered company has engaged in fraud through several media, both threatened an carried out illegal attacks against legitimate websites, and stolen private (occasionally valuable) information though misrepresented features of his software. Why hasn’t anyone ever called him on it?

Drunk On Java:

I say someone should reflect the attacks or RRA him. (Almost everyone doesn’t know what that is)

Ooo, aren’t you leet

Bang Train:

it is impossible to “crack” md5

Very possible, with a time/memory tradeoff application (i.e., rainbow tables).

item.title: We been DDOS 8 times in a row today
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

Taylor:

Did you know RaW cracks md5 hashes on the old ar2 scam boards? he did that to one of my friends

it is impossible to “crack” md5

it is possible to do the following:

  1. bruteforce SLOW HAS A MOFO

  2. Collision tables. Pgram that creates the collision table for a hash and you then create another string using that that has the SAME md5 yet diffret contents. In hex m,ode it differs by 16 bytes or so and has same md5 hash still. Also time consuming, have yet to get it to work
